answers.explanation:
The OCT macula of the patient’s left eye is shown. There is subretinal fluid extending nasally from the sub-foveal region (yellow arrow). There is also an extrafoveal choroidal pit located nasal to the fovea, called a focal choroidal excavation (red arrow). Focal choroidal excavations (FCE) are concave choroidal pits, often seen in the macular region that was first termed in 2011 (Margolis et al., 2011). The etiology and pathogenesis of FCEs are not well understood but these are often visually asymptomatic on its own unless accompanied by concurrent disease.

![](/content/media/r60_2.webp)

References

Margolis R, Mukkamala SK, Jampol LM, Spaide RF, Ober MD, Sorenson JA, Gentile RC, Miller JA, Sherman J, Freund KB. The expanded spectrum of focal choroidal excavation. Arch Ophthalmol. 2011. 129: 1320–1325.

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
![](/content/media/r60_3.webp)

The patient returns several months later, and a repeat OCT macula is performed as shown above.  Which of the following types of focal choroidal excavation does the patient present with?

answers.explanation:
Focal choroidal excavations are categorized into two main types: conforming and non-conforming.  In conforming FCEs (shown below), the overlying RPE and outer retinal layers follow the outward curvature of the excavation.  In non-conforming FCEs, the overlying RPE and outer retinal layers do not follow the outward curvature of the excavation creating a hypo-reflective space in between. 

![](/content/media/r60_4.webp)

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Which of the following conditions are focal choroidal excavations associated with?

answers.explanation:
Focal choroidal excavations have been associated with all three of the conditions above although it is unclear whether these conditions lead to acquired FCEs or whether pre-existing, possibly congenital FCEs, predispose patients to these conditions (Verma et al., 2021).  It is these associated conditions that often lead to the patient’s visual symptoms.  As isolated FCEs are often asymptomatic and can be difficult to detect on fundoscopy, OCT remains the gold standard technique in diagnosing FCEs.

References
Verma S, Kumar V, Azad S, Bhayana AA, Surve A, Kumar S, Agarwal P, Chawla R, Venkatesh P. Focal choroidal excavation: review of literature. British Journal of Ophthalmology. 2021; 105(8): 1043-1048.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: Which of the following are possible treatment strategies for this patient?

answers.explanation:
Cases of isolated focal choroidal excavations without concurrent disease do not need treatment as they have a minimal effect on vision and remain relatively stable.  In the setting of concurrent disease, such as with choroidal neovascularization, intervention with intravitreal anti-VEGF is a reasonable treatment option. (Xu et al., 2014).

References

Xu H, Zeng F, Shi D, Sun X, Chen X, Bai Y. Focal choroidal excavation complicated by choroidal neovascularization. Ophthalmology. 2014; 121(1): 246-250.
